Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Singapore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Luke J. Linhoff of Florida International University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at National University of Singapore in Singapore. The project title is "Testing Applied Amphibian Conservation Methodologies." The host scientist is Dr. David Bickford.

The term "translocation" is used to describe any anthropogenically caused movement of living organisms from one area to another. Amphibian conservation programs utilize translocations for endangered species reintroductions, habitat mitigations, species restoration, and rehabilitations. However, little research has studied the subsequent behavioral and physiological effects on amphibians following translocation. This project focuses on 3 goals: 1) developing a long term research plan to develop tropical amphibian translocation experiments that can be replicated on temperate amphibians; 2) performing short translocation trails comparing methodologies on a common leaf litter frog; 3) initiating testing to assess a non-invasive attachment technique for radio transmitters that will eventually be used to track amphibians.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this research will have direct and immediate application to a growing movement to save endangered amphibians. If conservation programs have more scientifically sound recommendations, it may be possible to save a larger number of species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I traveled to Singapore, Singapore where I worked with Dr. David Bickford's lab at the National University of Singapore (NUS). I worked with Dr. Bickford developing new conservation techniques for amphibians (frogs and toads) that can be implemented in Singapore to protect its biodiversity. We are particularly interested in movement, behavior, and ecology of these understudied animals. We helped plan a much larger project that will hopefully study how to reintroduce some rare amphibian species (that are found in only one or two areas) into other natural areas or parks to reduce the chance that they will go extinct. During my EAPSI tenure, I performed intensive surveys for amphibians and reptiles in multiple parks, I did many direct focal-animal observations tracking behavior, and I helped out with several other graduate students research projects where I learned new scientific techniques. As another part of my project, I mentored an NUS honors student. I taught her how to do standard surveys for reptiles and amphibians and taught her to Identify local species. I helped her design an 8 month long study testing a novel amphibian conservation technique, which she completed in 2014. The EAPSI award allowed me to meet and network with multiple researchers from NUS, Singapore National Parks, Singapore Botanic Gardens, and the Singapore Zoo. Most importantly, this award established a foundation of knowledge, research and contacts that I will now be utilizing to return to Singapore to continue my amphibian conservation research. It has allowed me to expand my PhD dissertation, and I will now be spending 4-5 months a year in Singapore doing novel conservation research that will be applicable to many endangered species found in the USA and Singapore.
